titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nicholas School of the Environment Records, 1916-ongoing UA.18.01.0001
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Michael Shumate, Stephanie Chao, and Julia Eads; machine-readable finding aid created by: Michael Shumate

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-06 21:34:19 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Nicholas School of the Environment records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Nicholas School of the Environment (Duke University)

did.abstract: Duke University's Nicholas School of the Environment traces its beginnings to the founding of the Duke School of Forestry in 1938. In the 1990s two other entities, the Duke Marine Laboratory and the Duke Department of Geology, were combined with Forestry to form the Nicholas School. The Records of Duke University's Nicholas School of the Environment, 1916-ongoing, contain materials created from the school's inception as the Duke School of Forestry (1938) through all its subsequent names: the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, the School of the Environment, and the Nicholas School of the Environment and Earth Sciences. The collection also includes material about the history of Duke Forest and its use as a teaching and research facility. The earliest materials comprise the papers of Clarence F. Korstian, first director of the Forest and first dean of the School, including his correspondence, early reports about the Forest and the School, and his involvement in the Ecological Society of America, the North Carolina Forestry Association, and the International Union of Forest Research Organizations. The bulk of the collection consists of the School's general administrative records, including annual reports, admissions records, enrollment statistics, information on degrees granted, faculty history and meetings, and surveys and meetings of the School's alumni. Visual materials include posters, color and black-and-white photographs, negatives, slides, and digital photographs that document the School of Forestry and the Duke Marine Laboratory.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Nicholas School of the Environment Records, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Nicholas School of the Environment Records were received by the University Archives as a transfer, 1974-2019.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Michael Shumate, Stephanie Chao, and Julia Eads, January 2013, Matt Schaefer, April 2014
All accessions from 1974-2014 were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.
Collection level access notes updated by Tracy M. Jackson, January 2019.
Updated with accessions UA2018.0045 and UA2018.0076 by [Matthew] Farrell, November 2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical and Historical Note
bioghist.p: Forestry studies at Duke University can be traced to 1931, when several of the nearby small farms and forestlands the university had been purchasing since the mid-1920s were formally named as Duke Forest. When the School of Forestry was established in 1938, it was the first graduate school in its field in the South. A chronology of its history follows below.

eventgrp.event: Clarence F. Korstian appointed as first Director of Duke Forest
First classes in forestry taught at Duke University
School of Forestry founded, with Korstian appointed as Dean
Curriculum expanded to include broader range of ecological sciences
Renamed School of Forestry and Environmental Studies
Merged with the Duke Marine Laboratory (founded 1938) and renamed School of the Environment
Renamed Nicholas School of the Environment following upon gift of Peter and Virginia Nicholas
Division of Earth and Ocean Sciences created when the former Department of Geology (founded 1936) joins school
School re-named Nicholas School of the Environment and Earth Sciences
Name reverted to Nicholas School of the Environment

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Records of Duke University's Nicholas School of the Environment contain materials created during the school's entire history, from its founding as the Duke School of Forestry, in 1938, through all its subsequent names: the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, the School of the Environment, and the Nicholas School of the Environment and Earth Sciences. The collection also includes materials about the closely-related Duke Forest, especially its history and the School's management and use of it as a teaching and research facility. The earliest materials here comprise the papers of Clarence F. Korstian, first director of the Forest and first dean of the School; his files include his personal correspondence, early reports about the Forest and the School, and material about several professional organizations, particularly the Ecological Society of America, the North Carolina Forestry Association, and the International Union of Forest Research Organizations. Following Korstian's papers, the bulk of the collection consists of the School's general administrative records, including all the following: annual reports, admissions records, enrollment statistics, and information on degrees granted; faculty history, curricula, and meetings; and extensive data on the School's alumni, especially alumni surveys and newsletters and meetings of the Alumni Association. The administrative records are supplemented by extensive visual materials; these contain a small selection of posters and other promotional materials about the School, but primarily consist of approximately 5000 color and black-and-white photographs, negatives, slides, and digital photographs that document a wide variety of faculty and student history and activities at both the School of Forestry and the Duke Marine Laboratory. Arranged in order by accession number, with several small, related accessions merged into single series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records, such as search committee files or others pertaining to employment where individuals are identified, are closed for 70 years.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Portions of these materials are restricted by donor request.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: For a period of twenty-five years from the origin of the material, permission in writing from the office of origin and the University Archivist is required for use of administrative records. After twenty-five years, records that have been processed may be consulted with the permission of the University Archivist.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access copies of electronic records must be requested through the collection guide and accessed in our reading room. Contact Research Services with questions.

did.unittitle: UA 74-115 and UA 85-51: Clarence F. Korstian Records, 1916-1960

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These two accessions comprise the records of Clarence F. Korstian, first director of Duke Forest and first dean of the School of Forestry, and cover some forty-five years of his career, both prior to and following his Duke appointment in 1930. Duke materials document his years at the School of Forestry and include early reports to the President, studies such as the Loblolly Pine Project, and his involvement in several professional organizations, including the Ecological Society of America, the International Union of Forest Research Organizations, and the North Carolina Forestry Association. Arranged in alphabetical order by topic except for the first folder, a 1959 interview of Korstian about his long career.

did.unittitle: Clarence F. Korstian: Forty Years of Forestry, oral history interview, 1959
Duke School of Forestry--Reports to the President Report, 1937-1948

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much of this correspondence relates to Korstian's appointment as Director of the Duke Forest and Professor of Silviculture, 1930. Includes President W. P. Few's A.L.S. to Korstian, 1930 July 4.

scopecontent.p: Reports, clippings, press releases, information on creative retrenchment, and a folder concerning the career of William Maughn and the establishment of the Maughan Memorial Lecture series. Arranged in alphabetical order by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records concerning admissions, commencements, committees, curricula, enrollment statistics, summer programs and sessions, and other administrative activities, predominantly from the 1970s and early 1980s. Arranged alphabetically by topic, except for the extensive Red Cedar Study, circa 1935, which is housed at the end of the accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The largest of these accessions, UA 89-54, and the four smaller ones primarily comprise FES Alumni Association activities and records and have been interfiled together, with original accession number noted on individual folders. Materials include alumni surveys, correspondence, minutes of the Alumni Association's Executive Council meetings, reunions, and routine mailings to members. A small group of general files, unrelated to the Alumni Association, is gathered at the end of these accessions: these include various annual reports and some files about the proposed phaseout of the School of Forestry in the mid-1970s. Arranged in alphabetical order by topic.

did.unittitle: Field Day Reunion, general information and invitations, 1984

Correspondence--Reed Kelly to Harmon L. Smith, 1980
"Directions for Progress: A Report to the Duke University Board of Trustees," 1980
"Planning for the Eighties: A Report to the Duke University Board of Trustees"; and "Planning for the Eighties, a Response," 1978-1979

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These two accessions primarily consist of memoranda, news releases, clippings, and other public relations material sent to the Campus Calendar, Duke Dialogue, Faculty Newsletter, and other media. Also includes correspondence and material about conference, workshops, and other events sponsored by the School. The smaller accession, 94-74 (8 folders) has been interfiled with the larger, though noted on individual folders. Arranged in order by the office's filing system codes in use at the time, as follows: DU (Duke University); FES (Forestry and Environmental Studies); MSC (Meetings, Symposia, Conferences); and PR (unidentified, but presumably Public Relations).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two alumni surveys, interfiled together, conducted in 1984 (unstamped) and 1989 (date-stamped). Questions posed to alumni include positions held since graduation, current activities, effectiveness of the school for training, and involvement in alumni affairs. Arranged in alphabetical order by respondents' surnames.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proceedings and other materials from various conferences and workshops sponsored by the School; in many cases, multiple instances of the workshops are represented, spanning several years. Arranged as received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Syllabi and other course materials from several instances of this workshop offered at Duke and in New Orleans and Portland in 1984-1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, printed material, photographs and negatives, and other materials concerning public relations, alumni affairs, and reaccreditation. Also includes alumni newsletters, the report of self-evaluation of the School of Forestry done for the Society of American Foresters, brochures, and annual reports. Arranged in alphabetical order by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, minutes, printed matter, photographs, clippings, reports, handbooks, and other materials concerning the administration of the School of Forestry. Although materials were received unarranged, the 2- and 3-letter filing codes were consistent with other accessions, so materials have been gathered by these codes and arranged in alphabetical order. The major groups of materials are as follows: BV (Board of Visitors); C (Courses); DF (Duke Forest); DU (Duke University); FES (or SFES: School of Forestry and Environmental Science); OAS (Organizations and Societies); and P (Personnel).
